The Hamilton College "Hot Button Issues" poll found that 75 percent of high school seniors back the legalization of same-sex "marriage" or civil unions. 
 
 <snip<
 
 Dr. Gilbert notes that on another "hot button" issue -- homosexual relationships -- the strong support shown by the seniors differs greatly from the sentiments of the general adult population. The educator thinks he knows why.
 
 "On the gay issue, I just think they've just grown up in a different time. There's a lot more openness about being gay, and I don't think it's something that bothers most high school seniors," the Cornell graduate says. "There's a minority of maybe 20 percent who are quite resistant to this."
 
 The survey also found that three in four seniors oppose a constitutional amendment banning same-sex marriage, and 63 percent support adoption by homosexual couples.
 http://headlines.agapepress.org/archive/1/122006b.asp

post_info.post_title: High school seniors bullish for same-sex marriage

 Ohh I am but what is good for the goose is good for the gander. If the cithgaps want to put my rights on the ballot I want to put theirs on the ballot.

What are cithgaps?

 
 It's Matt's made up term for "Christians that hate gay people" or something like that. It's actually quite an improvement from the sweeping generalities he was making before.

I can't wait for todays highschoolers to start voting. I truly believe that if all Americans voted, our political arena would be a much different place. 
 
 I think that alot of the younger generation feels as if their vote doesn't count. They are unable to see the long term effects of what they do today.
 
 As someone who has been able to vote for (approximately) 12 years and yet only voted twice, I completely understand. I never even thought about politics until about 3 years ago. I guess that I thought that the people who did vote knew what was right and would vote accordingly. I now realize that the people who vote are usually those who have the time to analyze each issue and/or candidate and vote for what is best for themselves or those who vote blindly (usually) following their parents lead.
 
 Regardless, I feel that most people vote without considering all of the issues. It seems that they have one or two issues that they feel strongly about and vote accordingly without considering the big picture.
